entry.title: Hybrid Server-Side Rendering for UI5: Bridging CAP and AI-Generated Views
entry.content:
What if your UI5 views could be generated automatically by AI and pre-rendered on the server before ever reaching the browser? This isn't science fiction, it's an experimental approach I've been developing that combines Cloud Application Programming (CAP) with UI5 server-side rendering and AI-powered view generation.

 

The Core Concept: Hybrid SSR for UI5

Server-side rendering in UI5 doesn't have to mean fully rendering HTML on the server. My approach takes a hybrid path: pre-populating XML views with data on the server using Handlebars templating, while still letting UI5 handle the final rendering on the client.

This creates a practical architecture that addresses two critical concerns in enterprise applications:

  • Enhanced Security: By populating data directly into XML views on the server, you avoid exposing raw OData services to the client. Users receive only XML files with the specific data they need, no access to full OData endpoints through browser debugging tools.
  • Improved Performance: Rather than making separate OData calls for each view, the application receives XML views with data already embedded, reducing round trips and potentially improving load times.

 

From Concept to Reality

I first introduced this concept at reCAP, where I demonstrated how to combine UI5 and CAP to implement server-side pre-rendering of UI5 artifacts. The session covered:

  • Pre-rendering UI5 fragments and views using CAP
  • How these two SAP frameworks can enhance each other's capabilities
  • My approach to implementation and ideas for future improvements

The goal was to show how leveraging UI5 and CAP together can elevate both frameworks to the next level.

Watch the reCAP session: Hybrid UI5 Server-Side Rendering with CAP

 

Taking It Further: AI-Generated Views

At Devtoberfest, I pushed this concept into really exciting territory by adding AI-powered view generation. This is where things get interesting.

How AI Changes Everything

Traditional UI5 development requires developers to manually create XML views for every entity, form, and table in their application. What if AI could do this work for you, not just as a one-time code generator, but dynamically, on every request?

Here's how it works:

  1. AI analyzes your CAP entity definitions - It understands your data model, relationships, field types, and annotations
  2. AI generates appropriate UI5 views - Forms for editing, tables for lists, master-detail layouts, whatever makes sense for your data
  3. Views are pre-rendered on the server with actual data from your OData service
  4. Instant delivery to the client - Pre-populated, ready-to-display views arrive in milliseconds

The Power of On-Demand UI Generation

This approach means your UIs are generated fresh when needed, rather than maintained as static files. Imagine:

  • Zero view maintenance: Change your entity model, and your UI automatically adapts
  • Instant prototyping: From data model to working UI in seconds
  • Smart adaptability: AI can generate different views based on user roles, device types, or business context
  • Automatic best practices: The AI understands your annotations and generates appropriate labels, help text, and validations

Watch the Devtoberfest session: Taking UI5 Server-Side Rendering to the Next Level with AI

 

Get Started: Available Resources

Ready to experiment with this approach? I've made everything available as open-source plugins and a demo application:

CAP Backend Plugin

ui5-cap-serverside-rendering-plugin
Enables server-side rendering capabilities in your CAP backend. Handles Handlebars templating, data population, and view serving.

UI5 Frontend Library

be.wl.serversiderendering.library
The UI5 library that enables client-side handling of server-rendered views, including custom routing and view management.

Complete Demo Application

ui5-cap-serverside-rendering-demo
A fully functional example showing how to integrate both plugins, configure routing, and implement server-side rendering in a real application.

 

Try It Out

This is an ongoing experiment, and I'd love to see what the community builds with these tools. Whether you're interested in the basic SSR approach or the AI integration, the plugins and demo provide everything you need to start experimenting.

entry.title: Re: Deletion of Basic data text in Material is not replic...
entry.content: Hi Mines, Are you using DRF to trigger material replication via IDOCs? Here is the official notes: DRF for material does not support message function ‚Äò003‚Äô (deletion). DRF for material always sends the full material. Solution options: 1. Using only ALE: Sending a segment deletion is supported in standard ALE (transaction BD21). This option doesn‚Äôt need additional coding. 2. Using DRF or ALE: This option needs additional coding in the target systems. If it is possible to determine which data gets deleted in the target system, you can also implement the IDoc inbound BAdI IDOC_DATA_MAPPER in the target system. In this BAdI, set the segment‚Äôs message function (MSGFN) to ‚Äò003‚Äô (deletion). This enables the IDoc inbound (usually function module IDOC_INPUT_MATMAS01) to delete the data. Br. Thomas

entry.title: Beyond UI5 Controls: Using Web Components Across Frameworks
entry.content:
When building UI5 applications, you need to decide: should you create a classic UI5 Control or use a UI5 Web Component? This question matters even more when your organization uses different frameworks and wants a consistent user experience everywhere.

I recently presented this topic at both UI5con and SAP Devtoberfest 2025, sharing what we learned from integrating custom web components into UI5. This work showed us how to keep a consistent look and feel across applications while going beyond the standard SAP Fiori design.

Watch the full sessions:

  • Devtoberfest 2025 - Beyond UI5 Controls with the Rise of Web Components - Detailed walkthrough with live demo

  • UI5con 2025 - Same Topic, Different Perspective - Original presentation with Q&A

Why Web Components Matter

UI5 controls have always been great for building SAP applications. They give you pre-built components with Fiori design, theming, and internationalization built in. No need to worry about CSS or making things look right.

But things are changing. Many organizations now use Angular, React, Vue, and UI5 across different teams. Web components let you build once and use everywhere. They work with any framework while keeping their style and functionality intact.

This helps organizations:

  • Standardize UI/UX across teams using different frameworks
  • Use company-specific design systems instead of only SAP Fiori
  • Share components between Angular, React, Vue, and UI5 apps
  • Save development time by reusing components

When to Use What?

Use traditional UI5 controls when:

  • Your app only uses UI5
  • You're happy with SAP Fiori design
  • You don't need cross-framework support

Use UI5 web components when:

  • You want Fiori design in non-UI5 frameworks
  • You need components for Angular, React, and Vue
  • You're building a shared component library

Use native web components when:

  • Your company has its own design system
  • You need company branding everywhere
  • You work with different technologies

Our Proof of Concept

We integrated Nova design system web components into a UI5 application. This meant creating proxy controls that connect UI5 to the web components, handling properties, events, and data binding.

Our demo app, a simple To-Do list, replaced standard UI5 controls with Nova web components. Everything still worked like a normal UI5 app. Check out the GitHub repository to see how it works.

What We Learned

Technical stuff:

  • You need proxy controls to connect UI5 with web components
  • Event handling sometimes needs extra code
  • Data binding requires attention, especially with components built differently

Deployment: Web components work fine with SAP BTP. You can keep your consistent UI while using all BTP features.

Current state: Web components work well in production, but the ecosystem is still growing. You might need extra code for some edge cases. It might be early for productive usage üòâ

What's Next

Web components are changing how we think about UI development in SAP. Traditional UI5 controls are still great for many cases, but web components give you more options.

As more organizations share their component libraries on npm, we'll see better standardization and teamwork across companies. It's not about picking UI5 or something else, it's about using the right tool for each job.

Whether you're a UI5 developer, an architect planning UI strategy or a consultant helping clients, understanding web components and UI5 integration will be useful.

Resources

  • üì∫ Devtoberfest 2025 Session - Watch the full presentation with live demo
  • üì∫ UI5con 2025 Session - Original talk with Q&A
  • üíª Demo Application - GitHub Repository with code examples
  • üìÖ Event Page - Devtoberfest event details

entry.title: Re: Automated mass updates for Asset
entry.content:
Dear Aalmayyahi,
To manage multiple physical locations per fixed asset in SAP, the recommended approach is to leverage Functional Locations and/or custom fields with structured hierarchies. SAP does not natively support assigning multiple physical locations to a single FA record, so a flexible design is key.

Following are 4 options to Capture Multiple Physical Locations.

1.Functional Locations (FLOCs) in SAP PM (Plant Maintenance)
Ideal when assets are distributed across multiple operational sites or need maintenance tracking.
Create a hierarchical structure of functional locations (e.g., Building > Floor > Room).
Assign each FA to a primary FLOC; for multiple locations, consider creating sub-assets or equipment records linked to different FLOCs.
This will enables detailed reporting, maintenance planning, and spatial tracking.

2.Sub-Assets
When a single FA card represents multiple physical units.
Create sub-assets under the main asset, each representing a unit at a specific location.
Maintains financial roll-up while allowing location-specific tracking.

3. Custom Fields or User-Defined Fields (UDFs)
When you need to store multiple locations but don‚Äôt require full FLOC functionality.
Add custom fields to the asset master record (AS03) or use classification and characteristics to store multiple location tags.
Lightweight and flexible; good for reporting without full PM integration.


4. Asset Master Classification System
For tagging assets with multiple attributes, including locations.
Use class types (e.g., 100 for equipment) and assign characteristics for each location.
Allows multiple values per characteristic and supports advanced reporting.


Hope this will help you

entry.title: Quick recap from SAP SuccessConnect 2025‚Äîwhat changed and what to do next
entry.content:
My field notes from SAP SuccessConnect 2025.

This was my third SuccessConnect, and here‚Äôs the thing, this year wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúanother HR event.‚Äù Under the new SAP Connect umbrella, the message was simple and loud: connect everything, achieve anything.

Below is my practical recap: what shipped, what‚Äôs next, and what to do with it.

The event in one line

When/where: October 6‚Äì8, 2025, Las Vegas (with a virtual day on Oct 9).

What‚Äôs new: SuccessConnect now runs as the HCM track inside SAP Connect ‚Äî one consolidated flagship event. The connective tissue across sessions: AI agents, trusted data, and suite-level integration.

Reality check: the scale behind SuccessFactors

A quick snapshot of the platform scale that every new announcement builds on.

  • 10,000+ customers (including 165+ with 100k+ employees) ‚Äî real enterprise load and variety.
  • 104 countries localized, with 700+ regulatory updates delivered annually ‚Äî the compliance engine under the hood.
  • 350+ partners and deep extensibility through SAP Business Technology Platform ‚Äî where unique processes live.
  • 40+ embedded AI models across the suite ‚Äî the baseline for agentic use cases.

SAP SuccessFactors momentum ‚Äî at a glance:

Why show this? Because the value of agents, skills, and analytics lands only when they ride on a footprint this wide and this governed. With that context, let‚Äôs dive into what actually changed.

SuccessConnect 2025 highlights at a glance

Main-stage snapshot: the themes came through clearly across AI, data, and workforce management.

  • New Joule Agents boost productivity across HR processes (Performance & Goals, Career & Talent Development, HR Service, Payroll, People Intelligence).
  • Workforce Knowledge Network brings trusted expert AIs (e.g., G-P and Galileo) into Joule.
  • People Intelligence on SAP Business Data Cloud is GA‚Äîsuite insights with an open data backbone.
  • SmartRecruiters acquisition completed : sets the base for modern, candidate-centric TA.
  • SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling‚Äîskills-aware scheduling for frontline and complex operations.
  • Simplified Global Leave in EC‚Äîcountry-specific compliance handled in product.

Lets deep dive now: 

1) Talent acquisition reset ‚Äî SAP + SmartRecruiters

What happened: SAP completed the acquisition of SmartRecruiters on September 11, 2025. At SAP Connect, SAP positioned this as the foundation for an end-to-end, AI-driven hiring experience across the suite.

Why it matters: For years, native RCM lagged behind candidate-centric TA. SmartRecruiters brings modern architecture, marketplace depth, and strong AI signals. Expect a side-by-side path first (governed via SAP BTP) as SAP aligns processes, data, and experience patterns.

2) Agentic AI becomes real ‚Äî the Joule Agents roadmap

Shift: From a single copilot to a team of role-aware agents embedded across SuccessFactors.

Announced for HR:

  • Performance & Goals Agent : GA next month. Gives managers talking points, progress context, and prep in minutes.
  • Career & Talent Development Agent : 1H 2026. Succession planning and talent moves with skills/context baked in.
  • HR Service Agent : 1H 2026. Front-door for employee questions; frees HR from repeat tickets.
  • Payroll Agent : 1H 2026. ‚ÄúExplain pay‚Äù by fusing time and payroll detail; flags anomalies.
  • People Intelligence Agent : 1H 2026. Conversational access to workforce analytics (via People Intelligence on BDC).

The new ‚Äúbrain trust‚Äù: Workforce Knowledge Network
Joule can tap external expert AIs. Two launch partners were highlighted:

  • G-P (Globalization Partners) : access the G-P Gia HR agent for global employment guidance.
  • The Josh Bersin Company : Galileo feeds best-practice answers for questions like ‚ÄúHow do we hire engineers in a high-cost location?‚Äù

Why it matters: This elevates Joule from helpful automation to orchestrated expertise, with guardrails from your data and policies.

3) The data foundation : People Intelligence on SAP Business Data Cloud

What shipped: People Intelligence (initial capabilities) is GA, built on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). Prebuilt insights exist today (recruiting, learning, succession, career development, performance & goals), with more slated for May 2026 (rewards, benefits, time, onboarding).

Open by design: BDC Connect enables zero-copy, bi-directional sharing of SAP data products with external platforms. First partners:

  • Databricks : generally available.
  • Google BigQuery : in public preview; GA planned H1 2026.

Why it matters: You can keep SAP data in place yet analyze it alongside non-SAP data lakes, without brittle ETL. This is the architecture that makes agentic AI trustworthy.

Core HR updates you can act on

  • Workforce Scheduling : Early Adopter January 2026. Skills- and demand-aware shift planning.
  • Enhanced Time-Off : Expanded country packs (AU/DE/US) reduce custom rules; review your Time Profiles and accrual carryover settings before enabling.

  • Enterprise Service Management : GA now; the HR service backbone the HR Service Agent will leverage.

What this means for your 2026 plan

  1. Get your data house in order. Prioritize EC and BDC data quality/governance; every agent and analytic relies on it.
  2. Re-evaluate TA roadmaps. Treat SmartRecruiters + SuccessFactors as the destination; avoid long commitments to yesterday‚Äôs model.
  3. Make BTP an HR topic. Integration, extensibility, automation, and AI all ride on BTP. Budget and ownership should reflect that.
  4. Adopt an open skills posture. Use Talent Intelligence Hub as the consolidation point for skills from partners (Beamery, Degreed, Korn Ferry, Lightcast, etc.) so People Intelligence and agents have a single, clean skills record.

Closing note: Jay Shetty‚Äôs keynote ‚Äî clarity, resilience, purpose

 The event closed with a high-energy keynote from Jay Shetty. His core message was simple and useful for HR leaders: clarity beats speed, resilience is trained (not inherited), and purpose turns tools into outcomes. In other words, the human system around your tech matters as much as the tech itself.

  • Clarity as a ritual: Define what ‚Äúgood‚Äù looks like for each process (hiring, performance, learning) before you automate it.
  • Resilience by design: Build ‚Äúsafe to learn‚Äù loops into deployments‚Äîpilot, reflect, iterate‚Äîso change fatigue doesn‚Äôt win.
  • Purpose in practice: Connect each release to a human outcome (manager time saved, candidate experience improved, frontline schedule fairness).
  • Gratitude & empathy as fuel: Recognize progress publicly; it compounds adoption far better than policy pushes.

Why this matters here: the year‚Äôs big themes - agents, skills, and open data‚Äîonly land when people feel seen, guided, and ready. Pair the roadmap above with these habits and you‚Äôll get the cultural lift your stack deserves.

Discussion

What did you see at SuccessConnect that will change how you run HR in 2026? Which agent is most immediately useful in your world ‚Äî and what data will it need from you to be effective?

Disclaimer:

  • Dates/timelines and product names reflect SAP‚Äôs public announcements made during SAP Connect 2025.
  • Opinions here are my own; errors are mine. If you see something I should correct or clarify, drop a comment.

entry.title: How Redwood Software and SAP are shaping the next era of automation with Joule Studio
entry.content:
Introduction

Over the past year, Redwood Software has taken major steps forward in our long-standing partnership with SAP, turning the vision of conversational, agentic automation into something you can see and use today.

As Field CTO at Redwood, I‚Äôve spent many years helping SAP customers orchestrate their most critical workloads. Our shared mission with SAP has always been clear: make complex processes simpler, more reliable and, ultimately, autonomous.

Embedding automation into conversation with Joule Studio

In my previous post, I introduced how RunMyJobs by Redwood connects with SAP Joule Studio to transform automation into natural conversation. Since then, we‚Äôve built a tech preview that demonstrates a use case for how RunMyJobs‚Äô interoperability with SAP Joule makes agentic orchestration a reality you can scale for your most mission-critical processes.

One example is an autonomous, unplanned SAP system maintenance workflow. Traditionally, this requires multiple manual steps and cross-team coordination to pause background jobs, stop dependent integrations and verify dependencies. The SAP BTP team often has to schedule, stop or undeploy iFlows ad hoc, while the Basis team handles job suspension separately. Thus, it‚Äôs a fragmented process filled with stress and risk.

Today, an SAP Basis administrator can take a more goal-oriented approach. They can simply tell Joule what they need to do: 

‚ÄúSafely execute the SAP system maintenance procedure, including a pause on all dependent workflows associated with the system to avoid job failures.‚Äù

Joule triggers the complete, pre-approved workflow across RunMyJobs and the relevant SAP systems. Acting as an interactive control tower for the entire event, it executes pre-approved RunMyJobs workflows, coordinates with integrations and provides real-time progress and approval updates through natural language with either business or IT users.

For example, Joule might respond: 

‚ÄúAll background jobs are paused, and Integration Suite iFlows are offline. Do you approve the system restart now, or do you want to send an approval request to the system administrator for a restart?‚Äù 

Once the administrator confirms, the automated workflow proceeds to the next step.

üëâSee Joule in action with RunMyJobs here:

 

What we learned building Joule skills

Working with Joule Studio‚Äôs low-code design canvas confirmed how quickly governed automation can be delivered through conversational interfaces. Our approach focused on four essentials:

  1. Natural conversation design: Translating how SAP users actually phrase requests into machine-understandable prompts
  2. Action orchestration: Linking RunMyJobs APIs or pre-built SAP Accelerator Hub actions for pausing jobs, managing iFlows and performing restarts safely
  3. Context and safeguards: Supplying metadata so Joule executes only on the right systems, with test harnesses for edge cases
  4. Governed deployment: Leveraging accelerated compliance checks provided by RunMyJobs‚Äô SAP Endorsed App Premium certification to reliably execute controlled deployment across SAP environments

How RunMyJobs and Joule Studio connect

The integration between RunMyJobs and Joule Studio allows your teams to innovate safely across SAP environments and in various scenarios. The process looks like this:

  1. Publish operations in RunMyJobs, such as starting or pausing jobs.
  2. Publish actions to the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, making them available as reusable building blocks. 
  3. Secure access through SAP BTP using API keys and role-based permissions. You then govern access to these operations within the SAP BTP Cockpit. 
  4. Combine these actions in Joule Studio to build skills that connect automation with natural language requests.

This framework lets IT and business teams interact with automation directly in their workflow tools, so it‚Äôs governed, auditable and ready for expansion.

The future of automation is a conversation

We are only at the starting line of what‚Äôs possible. The combination of RunMyJobs and SAP Joule is laying the foundation for agentic automation across finance, supply chain, HR, IT and beyond. As SAP continues to advance its Business AI capabilities, Redwood will keep embedding orchestration where it matters most: within the business conversation.

Learn more about how Redwood works with SAP solutions.

1) SAP Help claims: 
(..)Ensure that you have no open transports pertaining to any country/region that you would use as either the company code country/region or the foreign registration country/region. Complete any transports involving content for any such country/region in any system that you use for testing and in your production system before initiating the migration to RITA. Additionally, if you later activate any additional country/region versions, ensure that all relevant transports are fully complete before performing any RITA-related configuration or maintenance(...)

2) SNOTE: 2907372  

(...)RITA activation is possible only if all business configuration projects have been released. Activating RITA with open business configuration projects prevents the subsequent transport of content to your production system. This can cause potentially serious inconsistencies.(...)

 

  1. Could you point out specifically what changes are considered are country-specific in terms of RITA activation?
  2. What exactly do we mean by the term 'configuration project is released'?

entry.title: R.I.P. RICEF(W) and Happy Halloween
entry.content:
A slightly late Halloween blog this one, focusing on the haunting themes of RICEFW‚Ä¶

Way back in the dawning of current SAP history, when dinosaurs ruled the earth or at least old grey haired SAP consultants had their intros to SAP and the dawning of R/3, there started a concept of RICEF(W) objects. This was then latterly bundled into the ASAP methodology that later partly evolved to the Activate methodology. When I look around today, with what grey hair I have remaining, I still see clear signs across customers in Sweden (where I work) that RICEF is still very much alive and kicking. Then I even notice the term popping up occasionally in marketing and trainings from SAP.

This Halloween I encourage everyone to start the journey to finally put RICEF(W) to rest.

So lets look at what RICEF stood for again:

Reports: This originally is a GUI driven ABAP report, and latterly could then also include BW analytical reports, and then any kind of ABAP that could be executed from SA38 (etc).

Interfaces: This started out I think as flat file and IDOC based, and then morphed to include more modern technologies, web-proxies, ODATA and so as a concept is almost current (you could argue). But where does event driven technology fit into this picture I wonder. Is it an enhancement or an interface? (we often have borderline questions like this, and different teams can confusingly chose different answers in a large organization)

Conversions: Data conversions and then transformations

Enhancements: Mods, User Exits, Implicit and then Explicit enhancements.

Forms: Sap-Script then Smartforms, then Adobe PDF forms etc. (categorizing by print outputs is really old school!)

And W when used is for Workflows, which you could argue evolved to Build process automation.

But what really was RICEF(W)? Well we used it to catalog all of our custom development work in SAP. Back in the 2012s I have a photograph of all of my customers requirements in a large stack of documents, each of which represented a RICEF for our SAP implementation, it was our full RICEF Catalog. RICEF(W) to be fair has tried to morph over the years to fit with modern developments, but I still argue, it is not fit for how we should plan, design and build modern developments.

So today I frequently here the question: Should we still use RICEF(W). and my answer today is ‚ÄúHell NO!‚Äù.

My reasoning is: RICEF(W) encourages our developers to develop like its 1999, a good thing for Prince fans perhaps, but for modern developers we really need to move on. Clean core is the direction that we must all travel, and to achieve this we need to very much adopt the SAP best practice, and that really does mean removing RICEF(W) and so we must adopt a new direction.

Modern development encourages a decoupled component based build, where software components interact and can be plug and play replaced by newer versions, where systems can be freely upgraded without having to investigate all the custom built extensions.

So what is the alternative to achieve this?

Well the really good news is that SAP have new methodologies and frameworks, that are here and ready made for the brave new world we find ourselves in. In particular for this question I would point everyone to the SAP Application Extension Methodology.

In the old days we would get a requirement, and spend about five minutes before deciding it was to be one (or more) RICEF(W) objects.

In the new world we throw this approach away and instead we are given a 3 phase cycle (that is open to SAP and 3rd party technologies) to follow. Here I will just describe at a high level, I highly recommend studying the SAP whitepaper here, which is an excellent document, and shows some concrete examples. I would also encourage everyone to try to dry run follow through this document for an extension that they either already have (needs to be a modern extension), or are about to build. This way you fully learn how to use this new methodology.

The 3 phases of the methodology

  • Assess extension use case: The first being to really understand the use case, and the existing architectural context, and the business context. This means we are following a business first design approach, which then should result in us delivering something that actually meets the business needs (for our context).
  • Asses extension technology: we assess the extension target solution, taking our use case(s) and defining the actions application logic, system, and required data for the extensions, we then separate this out to extension tasks. The extension tasks are placed in extension styles that are Presentation, Application, Data (Think: Model = Data; View = Presentation; Controller = Application). These extension tasks will be implemented by component building blocks in our solution.
  • Define extension target solution: The third phase then takes these extension building blocks, and defines the extension target solution. This for me as a software engineer is where I start to see light bulbs flashing on. Now we are going to build our extensions in components (not necessarily in SAP), that are placed in one of 3 extension styles, and in the latest whitepaper this then also takes into account clean core classifications.

My current thinking then is that the old RICEFW is now replaced by an Application Extension catalog.

The catalog then could be represented as an equation, something like

AE01 (Application extension 01) = D01 + D02 (data extension building blocks) + A01 + A03 (Application extension building blocks) + P04 + P06 (presentation layer building blocks).

And we could then also have

AE03 = D02 + A03 + A05 + P04 + P07

An example of a Data extension could be the behavioral definition and implementation for say updating a customer master.

An example of an Application extension would be any necessary business logic implemented in SOLID designed classes

An example of the Presentation extension would be the Fiori UI or the API that we generate from our projection views and based on our annotations. 

This means our future solutions now are essentially a lego brick construction comprised of Application extension building blocks. This then gives us the flexibility to build other Application extensions, and reuse some existing blocks again.

We then need to keep a catalog of building block equations to represent all of our Custom Application extensions, and ideally track their clean core scores. We also need to keep track of the testing statuses and versioning of all of these components.

This to me indicates the need for thoughts around how to keep track of status of these new solutions? Possibly some new tooling is needed here (possibly a good first usage of the methodology to design this). The various versioning of the components, and testing statuses in particular, then how to connect these to the business processes and business capabilities for the organization all needs to be managed. Not all these thoughts and questions have answers yet, but I think the journey to our future development work has started, and its time for everyone to get on board.

So this Halloween I encourage everyone developing SAP extensions, to really study the SAP custom extension methodology, and to then say RIP to RICEF(W).

SAP Application Extension Methodology Overview | SAP Help Portal

sap.application.extension.methodology.pdf

Footnote 1: RICEF(W) should only be used to keep track of our legacy solutions that are not built in this new world, that cannot morph to this new world, as quite simply, they are not clean core and not decoupled, and then also not MVC designed and built, and so we should aim to retire these as soon as we can, they represent our legacy design and code debt, our clean core journey is to move away from these so that we can fully leverage the modern solutions that SAP are providing for us.

Footnote 2: Last but not least I would really like to thank @HrishikeshMangi who has been the brains behind a lot of joining the dots behind how the application extension methodology is our and hopefully too your way forwards.

Footnote 3: apologies to SAP if in places I may have used slightly the wrong terminology (this often happens in my blogs).

entry.title: The Evolution of Payment Methods in SAP ERP: A Journey of Automation and Efficiency
entry.content:
Presented by Rodrigo Em√≠lio (Financial Coordinator, Magnum Tires)
at SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2025

Context

Magnum Tires, with more than 30 years of experience and 96 branches across Brazil, has embarked on a digital finance transformation journey.
In partnership with MakeValue, the company implemented banking interfaces using SAP APIs to modernize and automate collections, payments, and bank reconciliations, achieving greater agility, transparency, and scalability.

Project Objectives

  1. Automate financial processes ‚Äî reducing manual operations in Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable.

  2. Improve processing time for registering and reconciling payments and invoices.

  3. Reduce operational and financial costs.

  4. Ensure scalability, allowing growth without proportional increases in workload or expense.

Scope and Integrations

The project implemented banking integrations through SAP APIs with multiple financial institutions, including: Santander, Ita√∫, Bradesco, ABC, Safra, BTG, Caixa, and Banco do Brasil.

The new interfaces developed by MakeValue,  replaced legacy VAN connections, enabling 100% digital, real-time financial operations fully integrated with SAP.

Results ‚Äî Accounts Receivable

  • Full integration with bank APIs for automatic invoice generation and tracking.

  • Automated clearing of paid invoices and complete audit logs.

  • 80% of receivables are automatically cleared.

  • Over 96,000 invoices generated per month.

  • Significant reduction in VAN communication costs.

  • The finance team is now free to focus on analysis and strategic decision-making.

Results ‚Äî Accounts Payable

  • Automated payments through APIs with real-time confirmation and status updates.

  • 97% of payables processed automatically.

  • Over 6,200 payments per month.

  • Reduction in banking fees and operational workload.

  • Finance teams are now more focused on improving cash flow strategy and efficiency.

Next Steps

  • Implement the Bank Statement API to further reduce VAN costs and automate the validation of banking fees and reconciliations.

  • Prepare the infrastructure for the new payment method announced by the Central Bank of Brazil, scheduled for June 16, 2025, enabling real-time PIX transactions 24/7.

Conclusion

This initiative from Magnum Tires showcases how SAP ERP financial automation, powered by APIs and digital integration, can deliver efficiency, cost savings, and innovation.

With the support of MakeValue, the company positions itself at the forefront of banking interface innovation within SAP, proving that technology is the engine driving modern business performance.

Lecture link here.

API Management  FIN (Finance) Banking

entry.title: Payroll EG Issue ‚Äì Need to Process Salaries in Non-EGP Currencies for Foreign
entry.content:
We are currently facing a challenge in our SAP HCM Payroll configuration related to processing salaries for employees working in countries outside Egypt. These employees are assigned to companies that operate in different countries and pay salaries in local currencies (e.g., USD, KES, etc.).

However, when we run payroll using the Egypt-specific payroll driver (RPCALCE0), the system automatically converts all salary amounts into the Egyptian Pound (EGP), regardless of the company‚Äôs local currency. This behavior does not align with our business requirement, as we need to process and disburse salaries in the respective company currency, not in EGP.

We would appreciate your guidance on how to configure the system to support multi-currency payroll processing, ensuring that salaries are calculated and paid in the correct company-specific currency without being converted to EGP.

Please let us know the recommended approach or any necessary configuration steps to achieve this.

entry.title: How SAP and PETRONAS Are Fueling the Future of Performance
entry.content:
Driving Efficiency and Innovation.

In Formula 1, every millisecond counts ‚Äî and behind every lap of precision lies a world of data, integration, and intelligent technology. The same principles drive the partnership between SAP and PETRONAS, extending far beyond the racetrack.

In its 50th anniversary year, PETRONAS ‚Äì the dynamic global energy group and long-time partner of the Mercedes-AMG PETRONAS Formula One Team ‚Äì continues to accelerate its digital transformation journey. One of the most significant milestones in this process has been its strategic partnership with SAP, through the adoption of SAP Concur for travel and expense management.

For years, PETRONAS relied on SAP‚Äôs traditional SAP Concur Travel & Expense (TVM) solution. However, as the platform reached its end of life, the company faced a familiar challenge: excessive customization costs and increasing complexity. This was the perfect moment to rethink processes and shift towards a more integrated and intelligent approach.

A Seamless Move to SAP Concur

Transitioning to SAP Concur was not just a system migration ‚Äì it was a business transformation. The move allowed PETRONAS to align travel and expense operations with the broader SAP ecosystem, which already serves as the organization's digital backbone.

With SAP Concur, employees now benefit from end-to-end visibility, covering every step from travel request to expense reporting. The system brings cost transparency, allowing users to clearly see flight, accommodation, and meal allowance options in real time.

Since its full rollout in 2022, PETRONAS has reported a 20% improvement in travel cost efficiency. This measurable gain highlights how digital integration can directly contribute to financial discipline and operational excellence.

Beyond Efficiency: Building the Future Together

But this partnership is not just about cost savings. PETRONAS and SAP are working together to co-innovate and future-proof business processes. The next frontier involves leveraging AI, particularly generative AI, to minimize manual intervention and automate monitoring, freeing finance teams to focus on strategic value creation.

As PETRONAS continues to push the limits of technology both on and off the racetrack, the collaboration with SAP reflects a shared mindset: continuous innovation, transparency, and performance.

Just as precision and data drive the Formula 1 team‚Äôs success, the same principles now power PETRONAS‚Äô financial operations ‚Äî ensuring that every digital pit stop contributes to a faster, smarter, and more sustainable future.

The S√£o Paulo Grand Prix: Innovation Meets Performance in Brazil

This weekend, attention turns to the Formula 1 MSC Cruises Grande Pr√©mio de S√£o Paulo, taking place at the iconic Aut√≥dromo Jos√© Carlos Pace (Interlagos) in Brazil. The event showcases not only speed and competition, but the spirit of innovation and performance that also underpins PETRONAS and SAP‚Äôs collaboration. (f1saopaulo.com.br)

From high-octane racing to high-impact business transformation, the connection is clear: whether on the track or in the boardroom, excellence and technology go hand in hand.

From racetrack to boardroom, innovation is a team sport. SAP and PETRONAS demonstrate how technology and vision can drive performance at every level ‚Äî turning data into decisions, and processes into progress.

Today, technology creates champions.
And as the largest European technology company, SAP empowers winners in sports, in business, and in your organization.

SAP Concur

entry.title: Top 9 takeaways #SAPConnect 2025
entry.content:
1. The "Global Maxima" Strategy: Why the "App + Data + AI" Flywheel is the Core Bet

What was announced: SAP's core strategic argument stays consistent - that "a seamless app, data, and AI flywheel creates the highest value". This model, where all three components are part of a single, integrated suite, was positioned as the only way to win in the new age of AI.

The "So What": This was a direct declaration that the integrated suite is superior to a "best-of-breed" approach. Muhammad argued that AI with the "broadest context" (drawn from a full suite) will always provide the "deepest value". He explicitly stated that standalone players focusing on just one or two domains "will then, by definition, struggle to create enterprise-wide value with AI". For SAP, this "out-of-the-box harmonized data model" is no longer just a nice-to-have; it's the essential foundation for achieving "global maxima" and avoiding the integration tax and "opportunity cost" of a fragmented landscape.

1. SAP's "App + Data + AI" Flywheel Concept

 

2. Joule, Agents, and AI Assistants: The New Operating Model

What was announced: SAP is operationalizing its AI strategy through a new hierarchy:

  • Joule: The single conversational "Gen UI" that acts as the engagement layer.
  • Agents: The specialized "tools" that perform specific tasks.
  • AI Assistants: Role-specific partners, such as a "Receivable Assistant," "Controlling Assistant," or "Sourcing Assistant", which have these agents at their disposal.

The "So What": This is the "how" behind the "what." Stefan's end-to-end demo showed Joule as the single interface to drive insights and actions across the entire business suite, from procurement-to-pay to order-to-cash. Priyanka's demo took this a step further, showing an "operations assistant" for a plant manager, which then orchestrated multiple agents (like the "asset health agent," "maintenance planner agent," and "procurement assistant") to resolve a complex machine breakdown. This signals a fundamental redesign of the user experience, moving from clicking through apps to orchestrating complex, cross-functional outcomes.

2. Joule, Agents, and AI Assistants_The New Operating Model

 3. The 5 Patterns of AI: A New Framework for Business Applications

What was announced: The keynote introduced a five-pattern framework to explain how AI will "fundamentally reinvent business applications".

The "So What": This conceptual framework is a crucial guide for business leaders planning their AI roadmaps. It shows a multi-pronged innovation strategy, acknowledging that different processes will be transformed in different ways. The five patterns are:

  1. Seamlessly embedded AI and agentic experiences.
  2. Agent-driven autonomous execution capabilities.
  3. Truly AI-native applications built from the ground up.
  4. App-less experiences driven by a conversational layer.
  5. No-apps experiences where the app is generated in real-time.

3. The 5 Patterns of AI_A New Framework for Business Applications

 

4. From Insight-to-Action... to Autonomous Execution

What was announced: SAP is aggressively pushing beyond simple AI recommendations toward "agent-driven autonomous execution".

The "So What": This is the end-game. The keynote stressed that this evolution will happen as "your colleague has built enough trust on the assistant's performance". Priyanka's demo of an "autonomous maintenance and repair operation" was the flagship example. The vision is for the system to autonomously handle an entire complex event - from detecting a machine failure to identifying orders at risk, ordering the spare part from a supplier, and dispatching the best technician,... with the human partner simply monitoring and approving, not executing the workflow.

4. From Insight to Action to Autonomous Execution

5. "Deep Research": Joule's New High-Value Skill

What was announced: A powerful new capability in Joule called "deep research" was introduced and demoed.

The "So What": This is where SAP expects to unlock "100x type use cases for value". Instead of just answering simple, transactional queries, "deep research" allows Joule to synthesize "vast amounts of internal and external data" to answer complex, strategic questions. The example of compressing a 6-8 week account planning process into "just a few hours" - by synthesizing history, surfacing drivers, comparing playbooks, and drafting a plan - is a tangible game-changer for any go-to-market organization.

5. Deep Research in Joule

 

6. Truly AI-Native Applications Arrive (Supply Chain & Ariba)

What was announced: SAP unveiled its first "truly AI-native applications", making good on the promise of its 5-pattern framework.

The "So What": This proves the framework isn't just theory. The new Supply Chain Orchestration solution was the prime example, described as a "GPS for your supply chain" that uses a "network knowledge graph" to analyze real-time signals, assess risk, and suggest alternatives. The major SAP Ariba source-to-pay suite update was also positioned as "AI-native", enabling an "agentic and autonomous" approach to procurement. For existing customers, the most important line was the promise that this Ariba update will be "a non-disruptive update... that will not require a re-implementation"

6. Supply Chain Orchestration

 

7. "Skills are the New Supply Chain"

What was announced: The "Future of Work" segment, featuring Chief People Officer of SAP, Gina Vargiu-Breuer and futurist Ian Beecraft, reframed the entire human-AI partnership around the concept of "skills".

The "So What": This segment's most memorable line was Gina's: "skills are the new supply chain". With the shelf-life of technical skills plummeting to 18-36 months, the focus must shift from static "jobs" to a dynamic "skills-first" approach. AI is positioned as the enabler, allowing employees to "stretch into adjacent territories and skills" - for example, a financial planner using AI to perform predictive analytics without needing a data science degree. This makes a strong case for SAP SuccessFactors as the critical platform for managing this new, fast-moving "supply chain" of talent.

8. Business Data Cloud Gets Smarter with "Intelligent Applications"

What was announced: SAP is expanding its Business Data Cloud offering with a new suite of "intelligent applications".

The "So What": This is the "Data" layer of the flywheel in action. The new apps: Finance Intelligence, Supply Chain Intelligence, Revenue Intelligence, and Consumer Products Intelligence ... are designed to sit on top of the harmonized data layer and provide the "broadest context" the AI flywheel needs. This move elevates the Business Data Cloud from a purely technical "data fabric" into a tangible value-delivery platform, providing the out-of-the-box insights that fuel the AI assistants.

8. Business Data Cloud Gets Smarter with Intelligent Applications

 

9. SAP Engagement Cloud: Orchestrating Journeys Beyond Marketing

What was announced: The launch of the new SAP Engagement Cloud, a platform designed to "harmonize business data into actionable segments, triggers and journeys" for hyper-personalization.

The "So What": The key insight is that "engagement" is an enterprise-wide challenge, not just a marketing one. The demos pointedly showed this new cloud working for HR (orchestrating an alumni event) and Procurement (managing a supplier compliance journey). By creating a single, unified engine for all enterprise touchpoints - across HCM, procurement, and service - SAP is delivering on the "global maxima" theme, ensuring that every interaction, whether with a customer, supplier, or employee, is seamless and intelligent.

entry.title: Display measure name with selected variable/prompt value
entry.content:
Hi Team,

I want to display the measure name with the selected variable/prompt value in SAC story table.

Ex: Story has a measure 'Amt' and a variable/prompt for Year. When user runs report by entering '2023' in the Year variable/prompt. The measure name should be displayed as 'Amt 2023'.

I know there is a work around, by placing a text box on the measure column name and enabling dynamic text. 

But it wont work in my case as number of measure column might increase based on filters applied by user. Because i am using dimensions in the column. So when users filters dimension members the number of measure columns increase.

If you look at the below image, 'Meas' is the measure and  'App' and 'Types' are dimensions in the column of the table. As per the image 'S1' is selected/filtered for 'App' dimension and 'T1' is selected/filtered for 'Types' dimension. Hence table shows only one column 'Col1'. The issue is the number of columns increase when user select/filter more values for 'App' and 'Types' dimensions. 

So to summarize I cant use Dynamic text work around in this case as the number of columns is not static. It changes with the user selection/filters.

The story is based on Datasphere Analytical Model (live).

Please let me know how to achieve this either in SAC or in the Datasphere.

Thank you,

deshmukhk

entry.title: Re: Warning Popup Triggering Unexpectedly in SAC Script ‚Äì Need Help with Conditional Logic
entry.content: Hi @govardhan_vegi98 üëã The issue is likely that your event handler is tied to the table‚Äôs general onSelect event ‚Äî which fires for any cell click, not just the WBS column. Try adding a condition inside your script to check the selected column ID before showing the message.

entry.title: The Next Generation SAP Enterprise Architect Learning Forum - February 23‚Äì26, 2026 at Newtown Sq. PA

If there is one event that every Enterprise Architect in the SAP ecosystem could choose to join, this should be the one.The Next Generation SAP Enterprise Architect Learning Forum 2026 is a 3.5-day multitrack conference hosted at SAP Americas' Newtown Square campus, Staring deep-dive pre-conference workshops on February 23, followed by three full days of agenda-driven sessions from February 24‚Äì27.

The learning forum is meant for SAP EAs to understanding current and emerging topics like transformation,  AI,  Evolution of Agents, Data Architecture, SAP Business Data Cloud,  and the Human Edge for expanding strategic influence of an Enterprise Architect.

Structured as a professional learning forum rather than a keynote-only event, it is designed to advance architectural mastery while strengthening the community shaping the future of SAP Enterprise Architecture.

You can mark your calendars already for the 2026 agenda while the registration is opening in the next 2 weeks.

You will have opportunity to join your peers, SAP experts, and industry thought leaders for four days of deep learning, hands-on sessions, and collaboration around the evolving role of the SAP Enterprise Architect.

entry.title: Configurer un Flux d'Approbation Flexible pour le Bon de Commande (SAP S/4HANA Cloud)
entry.content:
üìò Guide Complet : Configurer un Flux d'Approbation Flexible pour le Bon de Commande (SAP S/4HANA Cloud)

Ce guide est con√ßu pour tous les types d'utilisateurs, des utilisateurs finaux ("Dummies") aux consultants et utilisateurs cl√©s. Nous allons transformer une proc√©dure technique  en un processus m√©tier complet de bout en bout, incluant les concepts, la configuration d√©taill√©e, et un plan de test pratique.

Ce guide est bas√© sur la version SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 23081.

  • 1. üí° Concepts : Qu'est-ce que le Workflow Flexible ? (Pour les "Nuls" et Utilisateurs Finaux)

Avant de configurer, comprenons-le "pourquoi" et le "comment".

Qu'est-ce que c'est ?

Le Workflow Flexible est la m√©thode moderne de SAP S/4HANA pour g√©rer les processus d'approbation. Voyez-le comme un "robot" de routage intelligent pour vos documents.

  • Avant (L'ancienne m√©thode) : Les r√®gles d'approbation (strat√©gies de lancement) √©taient rigides, complexes et n√©cessitaient souvent un expert technique (un d√©veloppeur) pour √™tre modifi√©es.
  • Maintenant (Le Workflow Flexible) : Les r√®gles sont d√©finies par les utilisateurs cl√©s (Key Users) directement dans une application Fiori. C'est visuel, adaptable et ne n√©cessite aucun code.

Pourquoi l'utiliser ?

  • Flexibilit√© : Vous pouvez changer les r√®gles (ex: "Approbation requise si > 1000 EUR" au lieu de 500 EUR) en quelques clics.
  • Mobilit√© : Les approbateurs re√ßoivent les t√¢ches dans leur application My Inbox et peuvent approuver depuis leur ordinateur ou leur t√©l√©phone.
  • Tra√ßabilit√© : Vous voyez exactement qui doit approuver, qui a approuv√©, et √† quelle heure.

Le Processus de Bout en Bout (Exemple simple)

  1. Cr√©ation : Un acheteur cr√©e une commande d'achat (PO) de 600 EUR.
  2. D√©clenchement : Le syst√®me v√©rifie les r√®gles. Il voit que 600 EUR est sup√©rieur √† la limite de 500 EUR que nous avons d√©finie.
  3. Approbation : Le syst√®me bloque la PO et envoie automatiquement une t√¢che d'approbation au manager (ex: dans l'application My Inbox).
  4. Action : Le manager ouvre la t√¢che, v√©rifie la PO, et clique sur "Approuver".
  5. Lib√©ration : Le syst√®me lib√®re automatiquement la PO. Elle est maintenant officielle et peut √™tre envoy√©e au fournisseur.
  • 2. üõ†Ô∏è Guide de Configuration (Pour les Utilisateurs Cl√©s et Consultants)

Cette section d√©taille le "comment" construire le processus, en suivant pr√©cis√©ment la proc√©dure de vos documents.

  1. Pr√©requis
  • Vous devez √™tre connect√© avec le r√¥le : Configuration Expert - Business Process Configuration3.
  • Le workflow flexible doit d√©j√† √™tre activ√© pour le type de document d'achat (ex: NB) dans votre syst√®me. C'est une √©tape de configuration de base (scoping).
  1. Proc√©dure de Configuration (√âtape par √âtape)

Nous allons maintenant configurer une r√®gle qui exige une approbation pour toute commande d'achat du groupe d'acheteurs 003 dont la valeur d√©passe 500 EUR.

  1. Acc√©der √† l'application
    • Connectez-vous √† la barre de lancement SAP Fiori.
    • Ouvrez l'application Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders (F2872).
    • L'√©cran Manage Workflows s'affiche, listant tous les workflows existants7.
  2. Cr√©er le Nouveau Workflow
    • Cliquez sur Ajouter (Add) pour cr√©er un nouveau workflow.
    • Dans l'onglet En-t√™te (Header), saisissez un nom clair.
    • Nom du workflow : Test du workflow pour le bon de commande CEB.
  3. D√©finir les Conditions de Lancement (Le "Quand")
    • Allez √† la section Conditions de d√©marrage (Start Conditions). C'est ici que nous d√©finissons quand ce workflow doit se d√©clencher.
    • Condition 1 : Groupe d'acheteurs
      • Dans le menu d√©roulant, s√©lectionnez Le groupe d'achats de la commande d'achat est :11.
      • Entrez la valeur : 00312.
    • Condition 2 : Montant
      • Cliquez sur Cr√©er une autre condition (Create another condition)13.
      • S√©lectionnez Le montant total net du bon de commande est sup√©rieur √† :14.
      • Entrez le Montant : 500,0015.
      • Entrez la Devise : EUR16.
    • Note : Le workflow ne se d√©clenchera que si TOUTES ces conditions sont remplies (Groupe 003 ET Montant > 500 EUR).
  4. D√©finir les √âtapes (Le "Qui")
    • Descendez √† la section √âtapes (Steps) et cliquez sur Cr√©er (Create)17.
    • Type d'√©tape : S√©lectionnez Lib√©ration du bon de commande (Release of Purchase Order)18.
  5. Attribuer les Destinataires (Les Approbateurs)
    • Allez √† la section Destinataires (Recipients)19.
    • Affectation par : Choisissez Utilisateur (User)20. (Note : Dans un sc√©nario r√©el, on utilise souvent "R√¥le" pour plus de flexibilit√©, mais nous suivons ici l'exemple).
    • Utilisateur : Cliquez sur l'aide √† la saisie et s√©lectionnez les utilisateurs sp√©cifiques qui peuvent approuver21. (L'image montre la s√©lection de plusieurs utilisateurs comme Catalin Irinia, Laurent Sirot, etc.).
    • Cliquez sur OK22.
    • √âtape √† r√©aliser par : S√©lectionnez Un des destinataires (One of the recipients)23. Cela signifie que si une seule des personnes list√©es approuve, l'√©tape est termin√©e.
    • Cliquez sur Cr√©er (Create) en bas de l'√©cran24.
  6. Sauvegarder et Activer le Workflow
    • Vous revenez √† l'√©cran principal du workflow. Cliquez sur Enregistrer (Save)25.
    • Le syst√®me sauvegarde votre nouvelle configuration26.
    • Cliquez sur Activer (Activate) pour rendre ce workflow "live"27.
    • R√©sultat : Votre workflow est maintenant list√© et a le statut Actif (Active)28.
  • 3. üß™ Cas Pratique et Plan de Test (End-to-End)

Maintenant, v√©rifions que notre configuration fonctionne dans un sc√©nario m√©tier r√©el.

Objectif : Tester que le workflow se d√©clenche uniquement pour les PO du groupe 003 de plus de 500 EUR et qu'il est approuv√© automatiquement dans les autres cas.

R√¥les de Test :

  • Utilisateur 1 (Acheteur) : Un utilisateur standard qui cr√©e les commandes d'achat.
  • Utilisateur 2 (Approbateur) : Un des managers que nous avons assign√©s dans le workflow (ex: CB998000010 - Catalin Irinia)29.

Donn√©es de Base (Exemples) :

  • Fournisseur : 10300001 (Global Corp)
  • Mat√©riel : TG11 (Trading Good)
  • Organisation d'achats : 1010
  • Plante : 1010
  • Groupe d'achats (Conditionnel) : 003 (Condition de test) 30 et 004 (Contre-test).

Plan de Test D√©taill√©

√âtape

R√¥le

Nom de l'√âtape de Test

Instructions

R√©sultat Attendu

Test A : D√©clenchement (Cas Nominal)

    

1

Acheteur

1. Ouvrir l'app Manage Purchase Orders (F0842A) ou Create Purchase Order - Advanced (ME21N).

 

2. Cr√©er une PO avec : Fournisseur 10300001, Mat√©riel TG11, Qty 10, Prix 60 EUR.

2

Approbateur

3

Approbateur

2. V√©rifier les d√©tails.

 

3. Cliquer sur Approuver (Approve).

La t√¢che dispara√Æt de la bo√Æte de r√©ception. La PO est lib√©r√©e.

Acheteur

Le statut de la PO est maintenant "Approuv√©" ou "Envoy√© au fournisseur".

Test B : Contre-Test (Montant trop faible)

    

5

Acheteur

Cr√©er PO < 500 EUR (Groupe 003)

1. Cr√©er une PO comme √† l'√©tape 1, mais avec un Prix de 40 EUR.

 

2. Groupe d'achats : 003.

 

3. Montant total = 400 EUR (Inf√©rieur √† 500 EUR 32).

 

4. Sauvegarder.

La PO est cr√©√©e et automatiquement approuv√©e. Elle ne se bloque pas.

6

Approbateur

V√©rifier la Bo√Æte de R√©ception

1. Ouvrir l'app My Inbox (F086).

Aucune nouvelle t√¢che n'appara√Æt. (Test r√©ussi).

Test C : Contre-Test (Mauvais Groupe d'Achat)

    

7

Acheteur

Cr√©er PO > 500 EUR (Groupe 004)

1. Cr√©er une PO comme √† l'√©tape 1 (Montant 600 EUR).

 

2. Groupe d'achats : 004 (Ne correspond pas √† 003 33).

 

3. Sauvegarder.

La PO est cr√©√©e et automatiquement approuv√©e. Elle ne se bloque pas.

8

Approbateur

V√©rifier la Bo√Æte de R√©ception

1. Ouvrir l'app My Inbox (F086).

Aucune nouvelle t√¢che n'appara√Æt. (Test r√©ussi).

  • 4. üèÅ Conclusion

En suivant ce guide, vous avez :

  1. Compris les concepts et les avantages m√©tier du Workflow Flexible S/4HANA.
  2. Configur√© un workflow d'approbation de bout en bout, en d√©finissant les conditions de d√©marrage 34et les approbateurs 35√† l'aide de l'application Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders36.
  3. Activ√© le workflow pour une utilisation productive37.
  4. Valid√© la configuration avec un plan de test m√©tier complet pour garantir que les r√®gles s'appliquent comme pr√©vu.

 

 

SAP CLOUD PUBLIC EDITION 2308

 

Configurer un flux d‚Äòapprobation flexible pour le bon de commande (facultatif)

Dans cette proc√©dure, vous configurez les conditions de lancement pour l'approbation du bon de commande.

Dear customer,

There are two options:

1. Release the mentioned transport. (You will have to do this sooner or later anyway.)

If there are any concerns about option 1, please proceed with option 2.

entry.title: How the Tax Reform in Brazil Impacts SAP Users
entry.content:
Clique aqui para a vers√£o em portugu√™s.

Tax reform in Brazil is a topic of great relevance for companies that need to adapt to these legal changes. For SAP users, it is important to understand how the reform affects logistical and financial processes, be aware of implementation deadlines, and know what solutions SAP provides to ensure a smooth transition.

Implementation Timeline of the Tax Reform

  • 2026: The tax reform begins to be tested, with initial lower rates of 0.9% for the Contribution on Goods and Services (CBS) and 0.1% for the Tax on Goods and Services (IBS).
  • 2027: CBS comes into effect, replacing PIS and Cofins. The IPI rate will be zeroed, except for industrialized products in the ZFM.
  • 2028: Last year of ICMS and ISS without changes.
  • 2029: Gradual elimination of ICMS and ISS, with an annual reduction of 10% in their rates, as part of the replacement by IBS.
  • 2033: Full adoption of the new tax regime, with the extinction of ICMS and ISS.

SAP Deliverables
SAP is committed to supporting its clients during the transition to the new tax model. SAP solutions are being updated to meet the new legal requirements, ensuring that companies can adapt to the changes.

SNOTE: Note Analyzer tool
We strongly recommend using the Note Analyzer tool to organize the implementation of SAP Notes for this solution. Refer to SAP Note 3200109 for instructions on this tool and use the XML file attached to SAP Note 3561376 to list the SAP deliverables for Brazil's Tax Reform. The latest version of Note Analyzer introduces a feature that displays the implementation order in the "comments" column after importing the XML. Follow this order, even if some SAP Notes are not relevant to your business. Note that the tool provides the correct order but not a complete list of prerequisites for the SAP Notes. Therefore, additional analysis may be necessary to address potential dependencies.

Important observations during the implementation of SAP notes
For each SAP Note to be implemented, take a moment to read its textual content. This way, you can become informed about known prerequisite notes, manual steps to be executed before or after the automatic implementation of correction instructions, and be aware of other instructions. Reading the content of each note to be implemented can help avoid implementation issues and the need for rework.
Moreover, it is crucial not to proceed with the implementation of subsequent SAP Notes, leaving previous notes incorrectly implemented in the system (status: incompletely implemented), as this leads to a corrupted system and the absence of necessary contexts and objects for future implementations. Therefore, when implementing a list of SAP Notes, ensure that each note is implemented correctly and completely.

Support Resources
SAP provides several support resources, including:

  • SAP Work Zone - Brazil - Tax Reform Localization: It allows SAP customers and partners to share information and collaborate on matters related to the Tax Reform. This space is updated daily.
  • The Regulatory Change Manager tool: Announcements of legal changes and planning of solution deliverables.
  • SAP Note 3561376 - Tax Reform Leading SAP Note for reading: It describes the delivery and support strategy for the Brazil Tax Reform solution. This frequently updated SAP Note lists the solution deliverables as they are released to customers. Attached to it is an always-updated XML file to be used on the Note Analyzer, assisting you in the implementation of SAP Notes in the proper order.
  • SAP Note 3637842 - Brazil Tax Reform - Testing Limitations with SEFAZ for reading: This informational SAP Note highlights the processes not yet supported by SAP related to the Tax Reform in Brazil, especially regarding scenarios to be tested with SEFAZ. This note will be updated regularly.
  • KBA 3642384 - Brazil Tax Reform Troubleshooting Guide: In addition to explaining SAP's deliverables and providing direct links to the Regulatory Change Manager platform for Tax Reform topics, this Troubleshooting KBA helps resolve potential issues already identified during the implementation of SAP Notes. By offering solutions to common problems, this KBA is continuously updated to include new information.

SAP ERP - Help Portal

  • Tax Groups and Tax Types Added to Nota Fiscal
  • CBS and IBS Taxes as Statistical Values in Nota Fiscal
  • Define Tax Situation for CBS and IBS
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Sales
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using TAXBRA
  • Enablement of NBS for CBS and IBS Determination in Purchasing Scenarios
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using TAXBRJ Pricing Procedure
  • Fields Added to Nota Fiscal for CBS and IBS Taxes
  • Nominal Rate Calculation and Nota Fiscal Texts for CBS and IBS in Nota Fiscal Writer
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using RVABRA and RVXBRA Pricing Procedures
  • Determine Tax Situation for CBS and IBS Business Add-In
  • Fields Added for Nominal Rates in Nota Fiscal BAdI Structure
  • Field Added to Nota Fiscal Table for IBS Tax Calculation
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Purchasing
  • Enhanced Tax Determination with Tax Situation for CBS and IBS for Sales Processes
  • Fields Added to Nota Fiscal BAdI and BAPIs structures
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Goods Movement

SAP S/4HANA - Help Portal

  • Tax Groups and Tax Types Added to Nota Fiscal
  • CBS and IBS Taxes as Statistical Values in Nota Fiscal
  • Define Tax Situation for CBS and IBS
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Sales
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using TAXBRA
  • Enablement of NBS for CBS and IBS Determination in Purchasing Scenarios
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using TAXBRJ Pricing Procedure
  • Fields Added to Nota Fiscal for CBS and IBS Taxes
  • Nominal Rate Calculation and Nota Fiscal Texts for CBS and IBS in Nota Fiscal Writer
  • Base Amount Changes for CBS and IBS Using RVABRA and RVXBRA Pricing Procedures
  • Determine Tax Situation for CBS and IBS Business Add-In
  • Fields Added for Nominal Rates in Nota Fiscal BAdI Structure
  • Field Added to Nota Fiscal Table for IBS Tax Calculation
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Purchasing
  • Enhanced Tax Determination with Tax Situation for CBS and IBS for Sales Processes
  • Fields Added to Nota Fiscal BAdI and BAPIs structures
  • CBS and IBS Tax Situation for Goods Movement

Implementation Deadline for Customers
SAP customers must have the SAP solutions related to the tax reform fully implemented and tested by December 2025 to ensure compliance with the new obligations starting from January 2026.

Government Validation
Currently, it is possible to test document approval with the fields for the new taxes in SEFAZ's homologation environment, and optionally, to send them in production as well. SEFAZ's production environment will begin validating the new XML fields of NF-e related to the tax reform taxes starting in January 2026. Until that date, filling out these new fields is optional and, even if filled, should not cause rejection in NF-e approval.
From January 2026, filling out the fields for the new taxes will be mandatory, with legal significance, for electronic tax documents in the production environment. Non-compliance may lead to the rejection of the invoices.

Conclusion
The tax reform in Brazil represents a significant legal change, so be mindful of the deadline for compliance.
The SAP informational notes listed above and the troubleshooting KBA will be continuously updated to ensure you have access to relevant information as you update your system.
Utilize the available resources and engage in the Work Zone to clarify any doubts.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Convergent Charging 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
New Release

PUBLIC

 

October 2025

Dear Convergent Charging and BRIM community,

We are glad to announce that effective October 15th, 2025, the SAP Convergent Charging 2025 FPS0 release is now generally available for our customers.

With this release we have introduced few highly impactful features that will significantly benefit our customers.  These includes new Multiclient support of SAP CC, re-rating of contracts using shared allowances and introduction of Joule assistant with Conversational search to make SAP CC more robust, ready to handle new age subscription scenarios as well as help customers bring down saving on hardware and maintenance costs

Let's dive into these latest product features in detail highlighting our latest pricing and charging capabilities, as part of the SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM) suite.

Multi-client support for SAP Convergent Charging

In a typical SaaS business model, enterprises often operate multiple system landscapes to support various stages of their operations. For instance, a dedicated SAP Convergent Charging (CC) server for development, another for testing, and one for UAT or production. While such setups ensure isolation and compliance, they also introduce significant operational and cost overhead. Each server requires its own installation, maintenance, and upgrade cycle, resulting in higher total cost of ownership (TCO) and increased administrative complexity.

For SaaS providers managing multiple B2B customers or internal business units, this challenge amplifies maintaining several SAP CC servers becomes both operationally inefficient and commercially unsustainable.

With the SAP CC 2025 FPS0 release, this long-standing challenge is now resolved through the introduction of Multi-Client Support. Customers can now host multiple logical clients (such as development, testing or UAT) on a single SAP CC server, fully aligned with the client concept in SAP S/4HANA. Each client operates as a completely isolated box, with its own business and technical data thus ensuring data segregation.

With this feature you can not only reduces infrastructure and licensing costs but also simplifies upgrades and maintenance, making it a major step forward in enabling cost-efficient scalability and streamlined operations for SAP CC customers.

Figure 1: Multiclient support for SAP Convergent Charging

The Benefits

  • Massive cost efficiency, simplified upgrades and lifecycle management, consistent governance, and seamless alignment with S/4HANA multi-client strategies, empowering organizations to scale smarter, not heavier.

 For easier implementation from Cockpit

  • New Fiori app, Manage Clients, available in the SAP CC Cockpit that enables System Administrators to export and import clients, their related JCo destinations (used for the communication between an SAP CC system and an SAP S/4HANA system) and customer management areas.

For more information about this new feature, refer to Multiclient Management in SAP CC (New) topic on the SAP Help Portal. And refer to the SAP Note 3636174 - One SAP Convergent Charging system connected to multiple S/4HANA systems for implementation guidelines.

Re-rating for contracts using shared allowances within a sharing group

Imagine a global travel platform such as REX Corporation, offering a Flight Booking-as-a-Service platform to airlines and travel partners. Through this platform, multiple partner agencies or airline business units share a common monthly allowance of booking transactions or API calls under a sharing group. Now imagine that, in such a complex shared allowance setup, after the billing cycle has closed, REX Corporation discovers that a portion of booking transactions was incorrectly rated into the next month‚Äôs billing period. Since the usage allowance is shared across multiple contracts, this results in imbalanced consumption reporting, revenue leakage, and potential audit risks.

Until now, in SAP BRIM we supported end-to-end shared allowance management, however, support of automated re-rating for these shared allowances were not possible. As a result, such re-rating requests often had to be handled manually, thus increasing complexity and introducing a high risk of human error.

With the SAP CC 2025 FPS0 release, this limitation is now resolved. Businesses can now trigger a complete re-rating for all contracts within a sharing group that consume shared allowances, directly from Convergent Invoicing (CI). The system automatically re-rates the entire sharing group together, ensuring synchronized allowance recalculation, accurate billing adjustments, and audit-safe financial compliance, without any custom intervention.

Figure 2: Re-rating for contracts using shared allowances within a sharing group

Benefits

  • Improve support for B2B use cases using account split and/or shared allowances

To support this feature end-to-end, we have introduced enhancements across SOM, CC, and CI. For more detailed information about this new capability, refer to the following links:

  • More Information
    • Rerating of Contracts Using Shared Allowances Within Sharing Groups (New)
    • What's New in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 > Rerating of Shared Allowances
    • SAP S/4HANA > Subscription Order Management > Shared Allowances
    • SAP Note 3630401 - Recommendations for Using the Rerating Feature in BRIM

Conversational search through Joule, our AI copilot

With this release, SAP Convergent Charging introduces AI-powered conversational search via Joule, enabling users to simply ask questions in natural language and instantly receive answers sourced directly from official SAP Help Portal documentation. Now you don‚Äôt need to manual keyword searches or navigate through multiple SAP help pages, rather, get all your queries answered in a conversational way from the Joule.

This capability can be implemented through the new Joule plugin integrated into the SAP CC Cockpit, onboarding the conversational search experience seamlessly inside the product UI. It significantly accelerates onboarding, learning, and day-to-day operations for business and IT users. Please note: this feature is available exclusively in SAP Convergent Charging, private cloud edition.

Figure 3: SAP CC Conversational search

 

  • Benefits
    • Improve user satisfaction through the ability to express business requirements in natural language
    • Enable quicker access to user-enablement content summarized in a crisp answer
    • Save valuable time by avoiding browsing through a long search-result list and reading into several topics to find the correct information

For more information about this new scope item, refer to SAP Note 3617641 - Integrating Joule with SAP Convergent Charging for Conversational Search.

Other Enhancements

In addition to the features mentioned above, SAP Convergent Charging 2025 FPS00 also introduces other enhancements:

Enhancements of Web services for integration with SAP CPQ

To further improve integration with SAP CPQ, SAP CC now offers enhanced web services to support consumption-based usage charging directly during quote creation and management.

With this enhancement, CPQ can dynamically create range tables when a new quote is generated and also modify existing range tables during quote adjustments, enabling sales teams to configure complex usage-based pricing models with greater accuracy and flexibility. This significantly improves sales agility with more quotation process, pricing precision, and end-to-end automation for subscription and usage-driven business models.

  • Benefits
    • Improve the integration capabilities between SAP CPQ and SAP Convergent Charging

Find more detail about this feature from SAP Help portal: Catalog Management > Import Range Table Data from CSV  &  Import Mapping Table Data from CSV

 

Replacement of Core Tool functionalities by functionalities in Cockpit Fiori apps

As part of SAP CC‚Äôs strategic shift toward a modern, unified user experience, we are gradually transitioning key Core Tool functionalities into Cockpit Fiori apps. With the 2025 release of SAP Convergent Charging, this phased replacement has officially begun. As previously communicated in our April 2025 SAP Blog, the transition will be executed role by role, ensuring 100% functional coverage of the existing Core Tool. You can find the detailed announcement in the SAP Blog page.

  • In the first phase of this journey, the User Administrator role is now fully migrated and will exclusively use the Fiori-based "Manage User Accounts" and "Manage Permissions" apps within the Cockpit. This evolution not only aligns with SAP‚Äôs Fiori-first UX strategy, but also delivers a more intuitive, consistent, and future-ready user experience across the SAP BRIM suite.

The User Administrator role will use the dedicated Fiori apps available in the Cockpit: 

  • Manage User Accounts
  • Manage Permissions

Find more details, refer to the SAP Note  3589935 - Replacement of user account management functionalities in Core Tool by functionalities in Cockpit Fiori apps as of SAP Convergent Charging 2025

 

More Information

SAP Convergent Charging 2025 FPS00 has been released to customers on October 15th, 2025,  and is available on the SAP Software Download Center.

For more information on SAP Convergent Charging 2025 FPS 00, check out the following links:

entry.title: Re: How to add landed costs to the material cost when fre...
entry.content:
Hello @nithin_pranesh  ,

There are two scenarios:

  1. If the material is not yet consumed before you receive the broker invoice, you can use the Inventory Revaluation document to adjust the cost.

  2. If the material is already consumed, then while doing the GRN, create a Landed Cost document with an assumed value and proceed. Later, when you receive the actual invoice from the broker, you can reconcile and adjust the difference under the relevant expense account.

entry.title: KSS2 Incorrectly Calculates Cosntrol Costs
entry.content:
Hi Colleagues,

I need some help because looking at the control costs we keep our heads scratching. Maybe there is something we overlooked.

The case is as follows:

  • We have posted 5 Activities on a production Cost Centre. Some of the credit came from confirmation (like MFBF), some from KB21N.
  • There are number of Cost Elements posted on this CC.
  • One Activity doesn‚Äôt have corresponding Cost Element posted in this period.
  • All Activites and Cost Elements are included in a OKES assignment. There is no loose cannon.
  • All Cost Elements posted are linked to an assignment, there is no activity independent cost on this CC.
  • The Cost Centre is assigned to the Splitting Structure in OKEW.
  • There are Cost Elements which are assigned to multiple OKES assignments but on this Cost Centre, all Cost Elements posted is assigned to only one assignment. So, we have a 1:1 model.
  • 1 Activity Types‚Äôs actual price will be calculated based on activity quantity, the rest based on capacity. (act. prices indicator is 5 and 6, respectively).
  • No Activity quantity nor Costs planned for this Cost Centre nor we have scheduled activity only Capacity is planned.
  • The Actual Price calculation method is set to Periodic in OKEQ.

After running KSS2, we have a mysterious amount of 27.625 which was assigned to the activity which didn‚Äôt have corresponding actual costs, then added again to ACT01, and ACT04 got this amount as Control Cost. Doesn‚Äôt make sense AT ALL.

Any hint will be warmly welcomed.

Cheers

M.
